newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkey suspends some state spending until year-end.
newsitem.headline: Turkey suspends some state spending until year-end.

text.p: The Turkish government suspended all state and local administration spending except on personnel and security until end-year to curb the widening budget deficit, the Anatolian news agency said on Thursday.
It said Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan announced the suspension in a directive sent to all state institutions.
Public institutions and local administrations must get permission from the prime minister's office for all spending except on personnel and security sectors, the directive said.

The aim is to curb the rapidly expanding budget deficit. The 1996 deficit was initially budgeted at 861 trillion lira, but had reached 750 trillion at end-September and is expected to reach 1,300 trillion at end-1996.

Economists say the large public deficits, expected to reach some 10 percent of gross national product this year, are the major reason for Turkey's chronic inflation, running at around 80 percent a year.
